timeline.bodyText: What's in proposedPackages? Isn't it the full list of resolved packages that need to be downloaded? If that's the case, why do you need recursion here?
timeline.author: fengwang666

replies.bodyText: proposedPackages are the proposed trees. After dependency resolution and downloading, resolved packages should be registered in registry, and recipes as well as artifacts are downloaded. So in this step, loading resolved tree per registry info.
replies.author: wikimonkey

timeline.bodyText: The conventional way is to use assertThrows for asserting exceptions in Junit5.
timeline.author: fengwang666

timeline.bodyText: throws Exception is fine. In unit tests, you don't need to put all the detail exceptions in the method signature.
timeline.author: fengwang666

replies.bodyText: IDE did it for me. Yes, can use exception instead.
replies.author: wikimonkey

replies.bodyText: private method doesn't require java doc. The comment is just for helping understand. I can delete them since the method now is descriptive itself.
replies.author: wikimonkey

timeline.bodyText: This method will constantly re-run right if a package appears multiple times? Should you maybe check at the beginning to see if the package even needs to be loaded?
timeline.author: MikeDombo

replies.bodyText: It should trust the info in package registry at this point is correct. The package can appear in different trees. Circular dependency should be checked before dependency resolution. So I don't quite get what checks I can do.
replies.author: wikimonkey

replies.bodyText: Check that it was loaded already, and thus you don't need to load it again. If A depends on B and C depends on B as well, then B is "loaded" twice, right?
replies.author: MikeDombo

replies.bodyText: Good point. Please check the latest change.
replies.author: wikimonkey

timeline.bodyText: Can you add comments to these test to describe the scenario that you're testing, specifically what conflicts exist and how you're expecting that they should resolve. Since I know you thought about it for a while, it would be very helpful to us readers to have the insights you had.
timeline.author: MikeDombo

replies.bodyText: BTW, the test you specified is for testing load package function (last step). I plan to add a lot more tests on dependency resolution later.
replies.author: wikimonkey

timeline.bodyText: Shouldn't this be a class field so that the cache always applies?
timeline.author: MikeDombo

replies.bodyText: I would say not. Because one deployment one call of package resolution, the packages may got refreshed with newer version. If we would like to cache multi-versions of packages, I would say that is package store responsibility. I think this level of optimization should be sufficient.
replies.author: wikimonkey

replies.bodyText: The PackageRegistryEntry contains the version, right? So it is safe to just keep writing into the same map, right?
replies.author: MikeDombo

replies.bodyText: Why do we want to keep expanding on this map? Then you have to think about how to clean up it. The deployment is not time critical, what's the concern of reloading the packages?
replies.author: wikimonkey

replies.bodyText: My assumption would be that performing the load is expensive, so I'm thinking to trade off memory for speed. But if you think that loading is actually cheap then the cache that you've added here should be fine.
replies.author: MikeDombo

timeline.message: Try fixing coverage report from "missing line-rate"
cache loaded package so not to load again
mock package store, but not mock repository
explicitly invoke constructor in unit test to work around multiple instances of same type
